Literature Review: Transcription-coupled repair (TCR) is a unique and essential DNA repair mechanism that has been extensively studied in various organisms, including model systems such as Escherichia coli, yeast, Arabidopsis, mice, and humans. This phenomenon is characterized by the preferential repair of UV-induced cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers located in transcribed mammalian genes compared to those in nontranscribed regions of the genome. The TCR pathway involves a translocase that interacts with both RNA polymerase stalled at damage in the transcribed strand and nucleotide excision repair proteins to accelerate repair. In this review, we will discuss the molecular mechanisms of TCR, its role in mutagenesis, and the recent advances in understanding this complex process using genome-wide next-generation sequencing methods, cryoâ€“electron microscopy, single-molecule analysis, and other approaches.
